newsitem.title: SINGAPORE: Asian crudes firm, Tapis underpinned by Australia.
newsitem.headline: Asian crudes firm, Tapis underpinned by Australia.

text.p: Crude oil prices in Asia were firmer on Tuesday supported by strong futures prices and continued shut downs of Australian light sweet crude fields.
Major 70,000 barrels per day (bpd) Griffin and 90,000 bpd Cossack fields were shut down overnight as Cyclone Rachel approached.
The 10-15,000 bpd Barrow Island and the 30,000 bpd Thevenard were also planning shut downs. The heavier 10,000-bpd Wandoo crude was also shut-in by the storm, traders said.
The output losses were underpinning Tapis paper, but traders said they had not spotted any fresh buying off the back of news.

January paper Tapis was quoted at $25.60/$25.80, up from a day-earlier $25.25/$25.45. Brokers attributed most of the rise to overnight gains on Brent and NYMEX, but said the news would undoubtedly underpin the market.
Little fresh action was seen in the cash market.
A February Dubai cargo was heard on offer by a producer at quotes plus $1.00, with two partials offered at plus 97 cents.
A state-oil company was bidding the Dubai paper and overnight bought Feb/Mar from a European major at 65 cents.
Feb/Mar was assessed Tuesday at 55/70 from 63/70 in New York. The state-oil company was said to be bidding at 63 cents.
Oman discussions for March barrels started in earnest with debate centred on the premium.
The Oman/Dubai differential widened out to $1.04 from 86 cents, indicating achievable premium could be 10-15 cents for March compared with plus 30 cents for February.
But Oman's 80,000 bpd refinery is on turnaround in March which will put some extra Oman on the market. Seasonal demand might be slower also, some traders said.
